title-group.article-title: Predictors of Coronary Lesions Complexity in Patients With Stable Coronary Artery Disease

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Cardiology, Ataturk University Medical School, Heart Center, Erzurum, Turkey
2Department of Cardiology, Erzurum Education and Research Hospital, Erzurum, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Enbiya Aksakal, Atatürk Üniversitesi Týp Fakültesi, Kalp Merkezi, Kardiyoloji Anabilim Dalý, 25100 Yakutiye, Erzurum, Turkey. Email: drenbiya@yahoo.com

body.p: Uysal et al 1 state that the patients with congestive heart failure (CHF) should be excluded from our study and that the difference in ejection fraction (EF) between the groups in Table 2 may affect the result of our study. 2 Also, they mention the relationship between high sensitivity C-reactive protein (hsCRP) and CHF.
First, our study is retrospective, and since it was not a planned, numerous biomarkers and clinical characteristics regarding coronary heart disease complexity are not recorded.

Uysal et al 1 stated that the EF difference between the groups may affect the result of the study. Possibly they made this comment because they assumed that the study is a randomized-controlled study. As mentioned above, we examined 436 consecutive patients retrospectively. We divided these patients into 3 groups according to their Syntax scores. Thus, it is expected to see a difference in EF between these groups. Similar findings may also be expected for diabetes mellitus, previous statin use, high-density lipoprotein, low-density lipoprotein, and estimated glomerular filtration rate. Proper matching should be left to randomized-controlled study. Also, the difference in left ventricular EF and other variables between the groups in the univariate analysis are the main purpose of the multivariate analysis.

Also, Uysal et al 1 discussed the relationship between hsCRP and CHF although they have not specified that. However, the assessment of the CHF and CRP relationship is not one of the purposes of our study. Besides, our study results revealed that both CHF and CRP are different between the groups in univariate analysis. However, CRP was not an independent predictor in logistic regression analysis whereas CHF was.
